title-group.article-title: Effect of Metal Coordination Fashion on Oxygen Electrocatalysis of Cobalt–Manganese Oxides

contrib-group.aff: †Laboratory for Chemistry and Life Science, Institute of Innovative Research, Tokyo Institute of Technology, R1-17, 4259 Nagatsuta-cho, Midori-ku, Yokohama, Kanagawa 226-8503, Japan
‡Institute of Multidisciplinary Research for Advanced Materials, Tohoku University, 2-1-1 Katahira, Aoba-ku, Sendai, Miyagi 980-8577, Japan

license.license-p: This is an open access article published under a Creative Commons Non-Commercial No Derivative Works (CC-BY-NC-ND) Attribution License, which permits copying and redistribution of the article, and creation of adaptations, all for non-commercial purposes.

abstract.p: The oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) are the most critical reactions that limit the efficiency of fuel cells, water electrolyzers, and metal–air batteries. Therefore, a need exists to develop cost-effective and highly active alternative electrocatalysts for ORR and OER. This study investigates the influence of metal coordination fashion on electrocatalytic ORR and OER activities among three types of Co–Mn bimetallic oxides (CMOs): tunnel-type (CMO_T), layer-type (CMO_L), and spinel-type (CMO_S) structures. An electrochemical evaluation for CMOs verifies that CMO_L has the highest ORR and OER specific activities, which is relatively better than the previously reported bifunctional metal oxides. Additionally, atomic configuration analysis for the oxides suggests that the excellent ORR and OER activities of CMO_L result from the difference in Co and Mn coordination states. This paper not only presents an excellent electrocatalyst for alkaline fuel cells and water electrolyzers but also provides an important guideline for the design of oxygen electrocatalysts.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The energy and environmental challenges, including depletion of fossil fuels and emission of greenhouse gases, have created a need to develop alternative clean energy sources and efficient energy conversion systems. The power-to-gas approach, which converts electricity from renewable energy resources into portable and high-energy density chemical fuels, is regarded as a promising process. Therefore, practical and emission-free energy conversion and storage devices are highly desired. These include fuel cells, water electrolyzers, and metal–air batteries, which are expected to be crucial in creating a sustainable society in the future. For example, polymer electrolyte fuel cells and water electrolyzers use solid proton-exchange membranes such as Nafion to achieve high current densities. However, because of their acidic conditions, electrocatalysts in these devices are limited to noble metals only, such as platinum, ruthenium, and iridium-based compounds,1−3 and their expensiveness prevents the widespread use. In contrast, anion-exchange membrane (AEM) systems have attracted extensive attention over the last decade because their alkaline environment allows the use of nonprecious metal-based electrocatalysts.4 Membrane stability was a challenge when using AEM systems. Therefore, intensive research efforts have recently made significant breakthroughs in membrane durability for operating conditions.5−8 This has opened an avenue for the commercialization of AEM systems. Contrarily, regarding electrocatalysis in the AEM systems, the two types of oxygen electrocatalytic reactions, oxygen reduction reaction (ORR: O2 + 2H2O + 4e– → 4OH–) in fuel cells and oxygen evolution reaction (OER: 4OH– → O2 + 2H2O + 4e–) in water electrolyzers and metal–air batteries induce a large overpotential and cause insufficient power densities, which is one of the main concerns for practical applications. Therefore, cost-friendly electrocatalysts that possess prominent ORR and OER activities are highly desirable.

As alternative oxygen electrocatalysts, 3d transition metal-based electrocatalysts have recently drawn much interest because of their abundance and cost-effectiveness and have been explored among various classes of substances,9 such as metal (hydr)oxides,10−14 phosphides,15−17 sulfides,18 nitrides,19 selenides,20 and carbon-based composites.21,22 Because of their outstanding properties, such as facile synthesis, low toxicity, and high electrochemical activities, multimetal oxides have been considered as attractive candidates for oxygen electrocatalysts. For instance, spinel and perovskite-type oxides are well-known to exhibit excellent ORR and OER activities owing to the combination of metal elements, compared to single-metal oxides.23 Several previous studies have demonstrated that elemental compositions can significantly affect ORR and OER activities.24,25 The elemental effects on these activities have been primarily discussed through computational calculations, and these activities are considered to be relevant to many descriptors, including the d-band center,26eg orbital occupancy,10,11 O 2p band center relative to the Fermi level,27 the number of d electrons,28,29 and metal–oxygen covalency.30 For example, our group recently found out that orthorhombic calcium iron oxide (CaFe2O4) possesses excellent OER activity in alkaline media and that its OER specific activity is significantly higher than that of previously reported alkaline-earth or rare-earth metal-containing Fe-based oxides. Computational calculation of the geometrical structures of the compounds has suggested that the excellent OER activity of CaFe2O4 is attributable to the edge-shared FeO6 polyhedral connectivity. Kakizaki et al.31

Another important factor for ORR and OER activities is the geometrical effects of catalysts. For example, Kakizaki et al. demonstrated that in the case of β-phase manganese dioxide, the OER activity depends on the exposed crystal facet on the catalyst surfaces.32 These facet dependencies were also reported for LaCoO316 and LiMn1.5Ni0.5O4.33 Furthermore, some studies have reported that ORR and OER activities can be improved by bending or distortion of polyhedra comprising active metal and O atoms.34−36 Recently, the control of crystal phases was investigated to enhance ORR and OER activities. Long et al. compared the ORR activities of two distinct cobalt (Co)–manganese (Mn) spinel oxides bearing a cubic and a tetragonal phase, respectively.37 Additionally, crystalline polymorphism affects ORR and OER activities on manganese oxide,38,39 iron oxyhydroxide,40 and palladium/copper alloy.41 Besides such microscopic geometry, macroscopic morphologies are also keys to enhancing the ORR and OER activities. Several studies have attempted to construct catalyst nanostructures to enlarge surface areas and improve mass transports during the electrochemical ORR and OER processes. These catalyst nanostructures include enriched porous nanofibers and nanorods,42 template-constructed porous structures,43 and metal–organic framework structures.44

These reports suggested that geometrical effects play an important role in ORR and OER activities, while no study has investigated the influence of structural dimensionality on electrocatalytic ORR and OER activities. Such structural differences affect various characteristics, such as cathode performance for lithium-ion batteries45 and catalytic activity for aerobic oxidation;46 therefore, it may also affect the electrocatalytic activities for ORR and OER due to a change in electronic states. This paper presents the influence of structural differences on ORR and OER activities to obtain a novel guideline for designing promising oxygen electrocatalysts, among three types of Co–Mn bimetallic oxides (CMOs): tunnel-type (CMO_T), layer-type (CMO_L), and spinel-type (CMO_S) structures, as shown in Figure 1. CMO_T exhibits a bundle 3 × 3 tunnel todorokite-type structure of a MnO6 octahedral framework (OMS-1), where hydrated Co2+ ions conduct in the one-dimensional tunnel. CMO_L exhibits a stacked layered structure of Mn oxides, with two-dimensionally intercalated Co2+ ions. The interlayer distance can be changed by hydration conditions. CMO_S possesses a normal spinel structure, where the 8a site of Co2+ ions can conduct through three-dimensional an 8a-16c(vacancy)-8a path in the Wyckoff position in the Fd–3m space group. These materials show similarities in the host structures of a MnO6 octahedral framework and guest Co2+ ions, with distinct cation conduction paths. In addition, these materials are selectively prepared from the same procedure of an alcohol reduction process.46 By controlling the reaction condition, such as the metal source, water content, and reaction temperature, a variety of Mn-based binary oxides can be obtained. Here, we examined ORR and OER activities of CMOs in alkaline media and discussed the important factors concerning the control of the catalytic performances.

caption.p: Schematic of three types of Co–Mn bimetallic oxides (CMOs). Blue spheres and purple octahedra represent cobalt and MnO6 octahedra, respectively. These illustrations were drawn using the VESTA program.47

sec.title: Synthesis and Characterization of Materials
sec.p: CMOs were prepared through a reduction of permanganate (MnO4–) in a cobalt chloride (CoCl2) solution in 2-propanol. Their structures were successfully regulated by adding water to the reaction solution for controlling Co2+ coordination by hydration. The high-energy synchrotron X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of CMO_T, L, and S are shown in Figure 2a. In CMO_L, peaks are attributable to two types of layered structures; peaks at 4.61, 9.19, 13.77, 18.24, 31.79, and 36.88° (the interplanar spacing of d = 0.96, 0.48, 0.32, 0.24, 0.14, and 0.12 nm, respectively) are attributed to the buserite-type structure with an interlayer distance of 0.96 nm, while peaks at 6.27 and 12.71° (d = 0.71 and 0.32 nm, respectively) are attributed to the birnnesite-type structure with the interlayer distance of 0.71 nm, which formed by dehydration of the buserite-type structure during the drying process.48−50 In CMO_T, peaks at 4.61, 9.19, 18.24, 31.79, and 36.88° (d = 0.96, 0.48, 0.24, 0.14, and 0.12 nm, respectively) are observed. These peak positions are the same as those for the buserite-type structure, but no other peaks are observed, indicating that no structure change in CMO_T occurs during the drying process compared to CMO_L. Therefore, the strucutre of CMO_T is attributable to the 3 × 3 tunnel todorokite-type (OMS-1) since it has a rigid structure against dehydration.51 In CMO_S, peaks at 9.19, 18.24, 31.79, and 36.88° (d = 0.48, 0.24, 0.14, and 0.12 nm, respectively) are observed. The absence of the lower angle peak at 4.61° (d = 0.96 nm) suggests the different structure from either CMO_T or CMO_L, and possibly, it is attributed to the cubic spinel-type structure.49 Note that manganese spinels (e.g., hausmannite) usually have the tetragonal structure due to Jahn–Teller distortion of Mn3+ ions. However, in CMO_S, the Co/Mn molar ratio is lower than 0.5 as shown in Table 1, and the valence state of Mn is higher than trivalent from Mn K-edge X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) spectra (Figure S1). In addition, the Mn K-edge extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectrum shows a single peak at 2–3 Å derived from single Mn–metal paths, suggesting that no Jahn–Teller distortion occurred in CMO_S, as shown later.52 According to the above, Mn4+ partially exists in CMO_S to form nonstoichiometric cubic spinel Co0.88Mn2O4. Such behavior is observed in the Mg–Mn spinel oxide.53

caption.p: (a) High-energy synchrotron XRD patterns for CMOs. (b–d) TEM images for (b) CMO_L, (c) CMO_T, and (d) CMO_S.

fn.label: b
fn.p: Quantified by inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES) analysis.

sec.p: Figure 2b–d displays the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of the synthesized materials. The TEM images of CMO_L showed a stacked structure with a d-spacing of 0.69 nm, which can be assigned to the birnnesite-type structure; the value corresponded to the interlayer distance of Mn oxides in Figure 1. A lattice fringe derived from the buserite-type structure with a d-spacing of 0.96 nm was not observed, probably because the buserite-type structure was transformed to the birnnesite-type structure during the vacuum drying pretreatment for the TEM measurement. Additionally, CMO_T showed a bundle structure that had a d-spacing of 0.50 nm, which corresponds to half the distance in the Mn oxide tunnel framework; its rigid structure is maintained during the vacuum drying pretreatment, as described above. In contrast, CMO_S displayed lattice fringes with d-spacings of 0.47 and 0.26 nm, which can be assigned to the (111) and (311) lattice planes of the cubic spinel structure, respectively. The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images in Figure S2 highlight that the CMO_T, L, and S have flake-like, flower-like, and spherical particle morphologies, respectively, and that the geometrical sizes of the particles are consistent with the TEM observations. The particle diameters of the three types of oxides are summarized in Table 1. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas of CMOs are also highlighted in Table 1, and it exhibited a good agreement to the geometrical size of CMOs. The BET surface areas are used to normalize the ORR and OER currents to calculate specific activities of CMOs.

sec.title: Evaluation of ORR Performance
sec.p: The electrocatalytic ORR activities of the three kinds of oxides, bearing distinct structures were evaluated using an LSV technique in O2-saturated 0.1 M potassium hydroxide (KOH) solution using a typical three-electrode system, as shown in Figure S3. A rotating-disk electrode (RDE, 5 mm diameter) was used as the working electrode. Details of the electrochemical measurements are described in the Experimental Section. Figure 3a highlights the iR-corrected LSV curves for the three types of oxides with ORR current density per electrode disk area. The loading amounts of CMOs on the RDE were adjusted on the basis of the BET specific surface areas of these catalysts; i.e., the net BET surface area of CMO on each RDE was set to 0.63 cm2BET cm–2disk. Figure 3a highlights the superior ORR activity of CMO_L when compared to CMO_T and S. Additionally, the corresponding Tafel slope of CMO_L was lower than those of CMO_T and S (Figure 3b), which also indicated the favorable ORR kinetics in CMO_L. The electron transfer numbers (n) during ORR were further examined using a rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE). Figure 3c displays the ring currents and calculated n in regions where ORR currents appeared. The variable n of CMO_L was found to be above 3.62, which was significantly higher than those of CMO_T and S. Although the ORR in CMO_L does not completely follow a direct four-electron transfer pathway, the electrochemical analyses confirmed that CMO_L exhibits better ORR performance as compared to CMO_T and S, even though the ORR activity was lower than that of benchmark Pt/C (Figure S4). However, the three types of oxides contain different amounts of metal contents. We then calculated the ORR mass activities at 0.75 V vs. RHE, which were normalized by loading metal amounts per RDE area and BET specific surface areas of the catalyst particles, respectively. Because the conductive CNT support in the catalyst layer on the RDE can also catalyze ORR, the ORR mass and specific activities were calculated using the actual ORR currents of CMOs, which was obtained by the subtraction of the ORR current of the CNT at 0.75 V (Figure S5). Figure 3d demonstrates that CMO_L has the lowest ORR mass activity among the oxides, which was attributed to the much smaller BET specific surface area and larger particle size of CMO_L than those of CMO_T and S, as shown in Table 1. We also calculated turnover frequencies (TOFs) of the CMOs based on the loaded weight of metals on the electrodes and compare. The TOFs of CMO_L are smaller than those of CMO_T and S as shown in Table S2. Nevertheless, the specific activity (excluding the effect of surface area) expresses the intrinsic catalytic activities and is a more important characteristic for catalysts. The CV curves of CMOs in Figure S6 show that the shapes of redox peaks in the CV curves are different among CMOs. It indicates that the three types of CMOs had different surface characteristics. Thus, we adjusted the loaded amount of CMOs on the RDE based on BET specific surface areas. It is noteworthy that CMO_L displayed a significantly higher ORR specific activity, which was 4.4 and 5.6 times larger than those of CMO_T and S, respectively (Figure 3e). Furthermore, the ORR specific activity of CMO_L was comparable to or even higher than those of the previously reported nonprecious bimetallic oxides containing 3d transition metals that can catalyze ORR and OER in alkaline media (Table S1). Therefore, the ORR activity depends on the metal coordination fashion of electrocatalysts; i.e., a layer structure highly benefits the ORR activity.

caption.p: ORR performances of CMOs. (a) LSV curves at an electrode rotating rate of 1600 rpm in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH. (b) Complemental Tafel plots, which were extracted from the LSV curves in (a). X-axis indicates ORR currents per BET specific surface areas of loaded CMOs on the RDE. (c) Ring currents and electron transfer numbers (n) of reactions that were recorded using the RRDE. (d) ORR mass activities of the three types of oxides at 0.75 V, which were obtained by normalizing the current densities of LSV curves in (a) using loading metal amounts on the RDE. (e) ORR specific activities of the three kinds of the oxides at 0.75 V, which were obtained by normalizing the current densities of LSV curves in (a) using BET specific surface areas of the oxides on the RDE.

sec.p: The durability of catalytic performance is an important factor for practical applications. The electrochemical stability of CMO_L was then tested by potential cycling (load cycle) between 0.6 and 1.0 V in N2-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution. Aged CMO_L showed a negative potential shift for the ORR current, as shown in Figure S7a, which indicated that CMO_L deteriorates when subjected to a load cycle test. This deterioration is attributable to the repeated redox reaction on the CMO_L surface. Figure S7b shows CV curves after load cycles. CMO_L initially exhibited oxidation and reduction peaks at 0.8 and 0.5 V, respectively, which can correspond to the overlapping of several redox processes involving Co and Mn species.54 However, the peak currents decreased as the number of cycles increased, and finally, they disappeared. This indicated an irreversible redox process on the CMO_L surface when applying a potential. Consequently, CMO_L transformed and/or degraded, resulting in the deterioration of CMO_L.

sec.title: Evaluation of OER Performance
sec.p: Additionally, the OER performances of the three types of oxides were evaluated by CV scans in O2-saturated 1 M KOH. Figure 4a and b represents the iR-corrected OER polarization curves with OER current density per electrode disk area and per BET specific surface area of CMOs, respectively, which display the mean of the forward and backward CV cycles. The polarization curves were used to determine the OER overpotentials of each oxide, which are defined as the potential gap between the theoretical potential of OER (1.23 V vs. RHE) and the experimentally measured potential at a current density of 10 mA cm–2disk in Figure 4a. The overpotentials are 0.40, 0.40, and 0.42 V for CMO_T, L, and S, respectively. Additionally, Figure 4c shows Tafel slopes, which were also extracted from the polarization curves. The Tafel slopes show trends similar to the overpotentials; i.e., the Tafel slopes of CMO_T and L were smaller than that of CMO_S, indicating advantageous OER kinetics in CMO_T and L. Similar to the evaluation of ORR performance, the OER mass and specific activities at 1.65 V are displayed in Figure 4d and e, respectively. The trends of OER activity resembled those of ORR activity. CMO_L demonstrated the highest OER mass and OER specific activities when compared to CMO_T and S. The specific activity of CMO_L was 7.8 and 26 times larger than those of the CMO_T and S, respectively. Furthermore, similar to ORR, the OER specific activity of CMO_L was significantly better than those of the previously reported nonprecious bimetallic oxides, as summarized in Table S1, even though the OER activity was lower than that of benchmark IrO2 (Figure S8). Moreover, the TOF for OER on the CMO_L is larger than those of CMO_T and S as shown in Table S2, also indicating the highest intrinsic OER activity on CMO_L. Although good wettability of the catalyst surface can facilitate the release of evolved O2 bubbles from the catalyst surfaces and is beneficial for the OER process, the dramatic improvement of OER activity of CMO_L cannot be explained by the surface wettability of catalyst particles. Therefore, ORR and OER electrocatalysis is significantly affected by the structural differences of electrocatalysts; i.e., a layer structure extensively facilitates this electrocatalysis.

caption.p: OER performances of CMOs. (a,b) Polarization curves at an electrode rotating rate of 1600 rpm in O2-saturated 1 M KOH. (c) Complemental Tafel plots extracted from the polarization curves in (b). (d) OER mass activities of the three types of oxides at 1.65 V, which were obtained by normalizing the current densities of polarization curves in (a) using loading metal amounts on the RDE. (e) OER specific activities of the three types of the oxides at 1.65 V, which were obtained by normalizing the current densities of polarization curves in (a) using BET specific surface areas of the oxides on the RDE.

sec.p: Furthermore, the long-term durability of the OER performance of CMO_L was examined through repeated potential cycles for OER measurements in 1 M KOH. OER polarization curves at the initial and 500th cycles are shown in Figure 5, demonstrating that OER current at a lower potential near the onset potential was retained after 500 cycles, which indicated that the intrinsic activity of CMO_L did not deteriorate. In contrast, the OER current at a higher potential was slightly diminished due to the partial corrosion of a conductive CNT support, which led to the limitation of electron transfer in the catalyst layer. Therefore, the durability test showed that CMO_L exhibits a high durability during the OER process in alkaline media and is a highly promising OER electrocatalyst for practical applications.

caption.p: OER polarization curves of CMO_L at an electrode rotating rate of 1600 rpm in O2-saturated 1 M KOH at the initial and 500th potential cycles.

sec.title: Insights into the Influence of Metal Coordination Fashion on Electrocatalytic ORR and OER Activities
sec.p: Generally, the electrocatalytic ORR and OER activities are affected by the valence state of transition metals.55−57 However, only slight differences among CMOs were observed in the Co and Mn K-edge XANES spectra (Figure S1). This indicates that valence states do not differ among CMOs. To explain the exceptional ORR and OER activities of CMO_L, the local metal configurations in the structures were analyzed by the EXAFS spectra. Figure 6 displays the EXAFS spectra of CMOs. The coordination states of Co and Mn cations were determined by a fitting analysis, and the results are shown in Table S3 of the Supporting Information. The second coordination numbers of Co and the neighbor metal (M) were significantly larger for CMO_L when compared to CMO_T and S. The larger metal–metal coordination number on CMO_L can be a result of the drying step performed after the formation of the template structures in the synthesis process. The structures of CMOs were selectively formed by controlling the Co cation hydration. When hydrated water was eliminated by drying, the structures of CMO_T and S remained unchanged owing to the rigid frames of the tunnel and spinel structures, respectively.46 In contrast, the layered structure in CMO_L is flexible on the c-axis, which led to the interlayer spaces shrinking when dried.46 Therefore, the compression of the interlayer can induce a more-packed layered structure, leading to a larger number of Co–metal and Mn–metal coordination. It is well-known that metal–metal coordination plays a crucial role in ORR and OER activities38,58 owing to its effect on the binding sites and strength of intermediates on the catalyst surfaces. For instance, metal coordination significantly affected the OER activities on Mn and Co-based oxides,59 and the ORR and OER activities of Co-based electrocatalysts were improved when increasing the Co–Co coordination numbers.60,61Additionally, reports have shown that a larger number of Mn–Mn coordination induced a higher intrinsic OER activity of metal oxide polymorphs.38 These higher activities with larger metal–metal coordination numbers are consistent with the enzymatic oxygen reduction and water oxidation in nature using polynuclear metal complexes, which are required for four-electron ORR and OER in heme-copper oxidases62 and photosystem II,63 respectively. Therefore, the high intrinsic ORR and OER activities in CMO_L can be ascribed to the different conditions in Co cation coordination.

caption.p: EXAFS analysis of CMOs. (a) Fourier-transformed Co and (b) Mn K-edge spectra.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The influence of metal coordination fashion on ORR and OER electrocatalytic activities in alkaline media was investigated by evaluating the activities of three types of Co–Mn bimetallic oxides (CMOs): tunnel-type (CMO_T), layer-type (CMO_L), and spinel-type (CMO_S) structures. Of these, CMO_L exhibited the highest ORR and OER activities. The ORR specific activity of CMO_L was found to be 4.4 and 5.6 times larger than those of CMO_T and S, respectively. Additionally, the OER specific activity was 7.8 and 26 times larger than those of CMO_T and S, respectively. Furthermore, the OER performance of CMO_L showed sufficient durability in alkaline media during a potential cycle test. The ORR and OER specific activities of CMO_L surpassed any previously reported bifunctional metal oxides bearing two 3d transition metals that can catalyze ORR and OER. Furthermore, EXAFS analysis indicated that the excellent ORR and OER activities of CMO_L resulted from the difference in Co coordination states among the three types of structures. Therefore, this study has demonstrated the influence of metal coordination fashion on ORR and OER electroactivities; i.e., a layer structure highly merits ORR and OER processes. These findings not only highlight an excellent electrocatalyst for alkaline fuel cells, water electrolyzers, and metal–air batteries but also provide a novel guideline for an efficient structural design of oxygen electrocatalysts. Further elucidations by computational calculations to obtain more insights into the catalytic mechanism on each structural difference are currently being conceived in our laboratories.

sec.title: Chemicals
sec.p: Potassium permanganate (KMnO4), CoCl2, and 2-propanol were purchased from Kanto Chemical Co., Inc. (Tokyo, Japan). KOH (85%) was purchased from Wako Pure Chemical Industries, Ltd. (Osaka, Japan), and tetra-n-butylammonium bromide (n-Bu4NBr) was purchased from Tokyo Chemical Industry Co., Ltd. (TCI) (Tokyo, Japan). A multiwall carbon nanotube (CNT, 90%), with an average diameter of 9.5 nm, was purchased from Nanocyl SA (Sambreville, Belgium) and functionalized to hydrophilize, as reported in our previous paper.64 Briefly, pristine CNT powder was treated with mixed acid solution containing 95% H2SO4 and 60% HNO3 with a volume ratio of 1:1 in a microwave reactor (μReactor EX, Shikoku Instrumentation Co., Ltd., Nakatado, Japan) for 15 min with 500 W. A 5 wt % Nafion solution (product number: 274704) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Japan K.K. (Tokyo, Japan), and its cation was exchanged by the addition of 0.1 M KOH aqueous solution. Carbon-supported platinum (Pt/C, 9.8% Pt, product number: 10E10E) and iridium oxide (IrO2, 75% Ir, product number: ELC-0110) were purchased from Tanaka Kikinzoku Kogyo (Tokyo, Japan). All other chemicals were purchased from Wako Pure Chemical Industries and used as received.

sec.title: Catalyst Synthesis
sec.p: Catalysts were synthesized according to the literature.46 Precursor tetra-n-butylammonium permanganate (n-Bu4NMnO4) was synthesized by slowly adding an aqueous n-Bu4NBr solution to an aqueous KMnO4 solution under vigorous stirring. This was followed by stirring for 1 h. CMO_T and L: n-Bu4NMnO4 (2 mmol) powder was slowly added to a CoCl2 (2 mmol) solution in a mixture of 2-propanol (50 mL) and water to obtain a molar ratio of H2O/CoCl2 = 600 and 60, respectively. The solution was refluxed for 3 h. CMO_S: n-Bu4NMnO4 (2 mmol) powder was slowly added to an anhydrous CoCl2 (2 mmol) solution in 2-propanol (50 mL) to form a colloidal solution. The solution was stirred for 30 min at room temperature followed by the addition of deionized water to form precipitates. Previous work reveals that the amount of H2O affects the structure of the binary oxide,46 while the excess amount of CoCl2 does not affect the characteristics. These precipitates were collected by membrane filtration, washed with water and ethanol, and dried at 120 °C. Caution: n-Bu4NMnO4 can react violently with itself (the MnO4– anion can oxidize the n-Bu4N cation) and possibly catch fire; hence, it should be handled with appropriate care and stored under appropriate conditions (e.g., refrigerated conditions).

sec.title: Material Characterizations
sec.p: Synchrotron powder XRD patterns with a wavelength of λ = 0.775 Å were collected at the BL5S2 beamline of the Aichi Synchrotron Radiation Center. Samples were charged into Lindeman glass capillaries of 0.5 mm diameter and measured with a rotating stage and a PILATUS 100K detector. Co and Mn K-edge X-ray absorption spectroscopy was carried out using the transmission method at the BL11S2 beamline of the Aichi Synchrotron Radiation Center. The XANES and EXAFS were analyzed using the Athena and Artemis programs.65 For the EXAFS analysis, the k-range of FT was 3–14 Å–1, with a Hanning window of 1 Å–1, and the radial distance range of the inverse FT was 1–3 Å. Elemental analyses were performed using ICP-AES on an Optima 3300XL (PerkinElmer, Inc., Waltham, MA, USA). BET surface areas of CMOs were measured by N2 adsorption at 77 K using a BELSORP18 (MicrotracBEL Corp., Osaka, Japan). The masses of samples for the measurements were approximately 0.1 g. Samples were dried at 120 °C under vacuum overnight and measured without exposure to air to prevent moisture absorption. SEM images were obtained on a Hitachi S-5500 (Hitachi High-Technologies Corporation, Tokyo, Japan) with an accelerating voltage of 5.0 kV. TEM images were obtained on a Hitachi H-9500 (Hitachi High-Technologies Corporation, Tokyo, Japan) with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV.

sec.title: Electrochemical Measurements
sec.p: Electrocatalytic performances of the synthesized catalysts were evaluated using an HZ-7000 potentiostat (HOKUTO DENKO Corp., Tokyo, Japan) equipped with an electrode rotator (HR-301, HOKUTO DENKO Corp.) and a rotating-disk electrode (RDE, 5 mm diameter) formed of glassy carbon (disk area = 0.196 cm2). The working electrodes were prepared through the following procedures. A mixture of 1.0 mg of an oxide catalyst, 9.0 mg of the functionalized CNT, 0.12 mL of 3.3 wt % K+ ion-exchanged Nafion, 0.42 mL of IPA, and 1.46 mL of water was homogenized for 3 min in an ice bath and diluted using the same solvent mixture with Nafion to adjust the catalyst concentration followed by sonicating for 2 h to prepare catalyst slurry. The CNT was selected as conductive carbon to mix with low-conductive oxide catalysts because of its relatively high corrosion resistance. Then, 7 μL of the resulting slurry was dropped onto an RDE and dried by rotation with 600 rpm in air. The loading amount of the oxide catalysts was set to 0.63 cm2BET cm–2disk and 0.018 mg cm–2disk for ORR and OER measurements, respectively. The electrode sample of IrO2 was also prepared by the same protocol. The Pt/C catalyst slurry was also prepared by sonicating a mixture of Pt/C (10 mg), 5 wt % Nafion (0.2 mL), and ethanol (2.0 mL) for 3 h, and 4.2 μL of the resulting slurry was dropped onto the glassy carbon disk electrode and dried by rotation with 600 rpm in air.

Figure S3 shows the setup of the electrochemical measurements. Hg/HgO (1 M KOH) and Pt were used as the reference and counter electrodes, respectively. The glass electrolysis cell includes a gas inlet, and electrolytes were saturated by N2 (30 min) or O2 (1 h) bubbling prior to measurements. The potential was converted to RHE. The calibration of Hg/HgO was conducted using Li et al.’s method.66 For calibration, electrolyte solutions (i.e., 0.1 and 1 M KOH) were saturated with pure hydrogen by bubbling for 60 min. Hg/HgO and Pt were used as the reference and counter electrodes, respectively. A Pt disk was used as the working electrode. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves were recorded at a scan rate of 1 mV s–1. The recorded LSV curves are shown in Figure S9. The potential of the LSV curve that crossed zero current was used to calibrate Hg/HgO to the RHE using eqs 1 and 212

The sample electrodes were pretreated by 10 cyclic voltammetry (CV) scans between 0.1 and 1.2 V vs. RHE at a scan rate of 50 mV s–1. The Ohmic losses were corrected using eq 3, the measured current (i), and an electrolyte resistance (R), which was measured by ac impedance3

The ORR activities of the oxides were examined by an LSV scan from 0.1 to 1.1 V vs. RHE with an electrode rotation speed of 1600 rpm at a scan rate of 10 mV s–1 in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH at ambient temperature. Electrolyte solutions were saturated by O2 bubbling for 1 h prior to the measurements. The background correction to cancel capacitive currents was carried out using an LSV curve in N2-saturated 0.1 M KOH without electrode rotation.67 The electron transfer number (n) during ORR was examined using an RRDE in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution at an electrode rotation speed of 1600 rpm. The ring potential was set at 1.39 V vs. RHE. The n was calculated using eq 4, where id is the disk current, ir is the ring current, and N is the collection efficiency of the ring electrode (0.37)4

Furthermore, the OER activities of the oxides were examined by CV scan sweeps between 1.2 and 1.8 V vs. RHE with an electrode rotation speed of 1600 rpm at a scan rate of 10 mV s–1 in O2-saturated 1 M KOH at ambient temperature. OER currents were obtained from taking the average of forward and backward sweep of the 10th cycle to ensure that the capacitive currents had been removed.68 Electrolyte solutions were saturated by O2 bubbling for 1 h prior to the measurements. To compare the intrinsic activities of CMOs, ORR and OER specific activities were calculated by normalizing measured currents using BET specific surface areas.

The turnover frequencies (TOFs) of ORR and OER for CMOs were calculated by eqs 5(69) and 7,70 respectively5where ik is the ORR kinetic current, which is expressed by eq 6, and n is the moles of the loaded Co and Mn atoms on the RDE.6where i is measured ORR current at 0.75 V, and il is the ORR mass transport limited current.7where i is the OER current at 1.65 V, and n is the moles of the loaded Co and Mn atoms on the RDE.

notes.title: Supporting Information Available
notes.p:
The Supporting Information is available free of charge at https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acsomega.0c04254.
Illustration of the setup for electrochemical measurements, additional experimental data of SEM images, electrochemical measurement results, and X-ray absorption spectroscopy analyses, as well as comparison of activities with previously reported ORR/OER bifunctional catalysts (PDF)

notes.title: Author Contributions
notes.p: § Y.S. and H.K. contributed equally. The manuscript was written through contributions of all authors. All authors have given approval to the final version of the manuscript.
The authors declare no competing financial interest.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: This study was performed under the Research Program of “Network Joint Research Center for Materials and Devices: Dynamic Alliance for Open Innovation Bridging Human, Environment and Materials”. The authors thank B. Eng. Satomi Ueno for the calibration of the reference electrode.
